markdown: Page 2 -- Group No. 3 8. That professional and voluntary national organizations interested in combatting malnutrition be encouraged by the USAIDs and their professional journals be adequately supported. 9. That the War on Hunger Office take over the support of nutrition surveys of the type carried out for many years by the ICNND and that a follow-up on the recommendations of these surveys be anticipated and made part of the project agreement with the host country. It is further recommended that the information elicited by these surveys be popularized and, whenever needed, translated into the language of the country for dissemination by the local press. 10. In order to increase the awareness of the population, it is recommended that programs involving nutrition rehabilitation centers, mother craft centers, and activators be encouraged by the USAIDs. That the Office of War on Hunger provide the USAIDs with information regarding such programs and place at the disposal of the USAIDs documents allowing Missions to reap the benefits of previous experiences in these programs. It is further suggested that the possibility of using local people as an indigenous Peace Corps be thoroughly explored and that wherever possible the new type of local Red Cross personnel be used. 11. The War on Hunger Office include in its program procedures that would bring nutrition information to the people of developing countries; that said Office evaluate and inventory existing material and consider supporting the writing of textbooks for school education in nutrition geared to local resources and foods. 12. That synoptic resumes of information pertaining to the state of nutrition in countries of AID interest be written up and disseminated to AID personnel in those countries and to relevant personnel from the host country government staffs. Source: https://www.industrydocuments.ucsf.edu/docs/mldg0227

chunks.markdown: 8. That professional and voluntary national organizations interested in combatting malnutrition be encouraged by the USAIDs and their professional journals be adequately supported. 9. That the War on Hunger Office take over the support of nutrition surveys of the type carried out for many years by the ICNND and that a follow-up on the recommendations of these surveys be anticipated and made part of the project agreement with the host country. It is further recommended that the information elicited by these surveys be popularized and, whenever needed, translated into the language of the country for dissemination by the local press.

10. In order to increase the awareness of the population, it is recommended that programs involving nutrition rehabilitation centers, mother craft centers, and activators be encouraged by the USAIDs. That the Office of War on Hunger provide the USAIDs with information regarding such programs and place at the disposal of the USAIDs documents allowing Missions to reap the benefits of previous experiences in these programs. It is further suggested that the possibility of using local people as an indigenous Peace Corps be thoroughly explored and that wherever possible the new type of local Red Cross personnel be used.

11. The War on Hunger Office include in its program procedures that would bring nutrition information to the people of developing countries; that said Office evaluate and inventory existing material and consider supporting the writing of textbooks for school education in nutrition geared to local resources and foods.

12. That synoptic resumes of information pertaining to the state of nutrition in countries of AID interest be written up and disseminated to AID personnel in those countries and to relevant personnel from the host country government staffs.
